column8:
Cheerwine soda has been a southern tradition since it was first introduced in Sailsbury, North Carolina in 1917.  Like other southern sodas (e.g., Royal Crown), Cheerwine is a little sweeter and less heavily carbonated.  Don't leave the lid off bottles of Cheerwine for long - it will go completely flat.  The taste is mellow and unusual, not at all like cherry cola or cherry 7UP - more like cream soda with cherries added.  I first tasted Cheerwine when I moved to North Carolina a few years ago; it was unlike any other soda I'd had before, and I buy it often now.

Today, Cheerwine is available throughout the South and serves as the perfect accompaniment to a humid summer day.  The company even has a website with recipes, including a rather tasty-sounding BBQ sauce.  If you're looking for a good old-fashioned taste of the South, try out this appealing soda.
column11: ['Grocery & Gourmet Food', 'Beverages', 'Bottled Beverages, Water & Drink Mixes', 'Soft Drinks']
column12: ['Created in 1917 in Salisbury, North Carolina by a general store owner named L.D. Peeler, this singular soft drink with a hint of wild cherry and a bubbly effervescence became an immediate hit. Folks from all around the county came to LD\'s store to give it a try.\n\nSoon cold cases all over North Carolina were filled with the "Nectar of North Carolina." It was known to put a smile on everyone\'s lips who gave it a try, and the Legend was born.', 'Statements regarding dietary supplements have not been evaluated by the FDA and are not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease or health condition.']
column13: Cheerwine Cherry Soda Drink (24 Cans)

column8: I spent a few years living in North Carolina and still get cravings for this soda (not too mention the ice cream sold in a few super markets). This is not a cola at all. The color is pink and the flavor is all cherry. This does not taste like Cherry 7up or Ginger Ale, but fans of those sodas may well enjoy Cheerwine. Between Cheerwine and Royal Crown Cola, the classic taste of the south comes through.

column8: If you are looking for Cherry soda this is not it.  It is more like a cherry cola.  It is okay but nothing I would order again.  The only cherry soda I have found is OSO Cherry but it is very difficult to find.  There is another brand of Cherry soda that you can get in  a couple places in the country but very difficult to find and most places will not ship it.  If you know of any real Cherry soda I would like to hear from you.

column8: I first tried the regular Cheerwine a few weeks ago and it quickly became one of my favorite sodas. I am a huge soda fan and quite often I get diet versions of soda because of the sheer quantity I drink. The Cheerwine with sugar is awesome, but the diet version is horrible.  The diet cherry Cheerwine is partially flat, weak flavor and mildly carbonated.  It has artifice sweetness, but does not taste sweet like other diet sodas.  The flavor is weak compared to the sugar version.  This lack of flavor and sweetness makes it like a seltzer water.  It would be okay as a mild flavor seltzer water if the carbonation was better, but that area lacks too.  It basically taste like a weak flavored, partially flat seltzer water.

column8: Cheerwine Cherry Fridge Pack Soft Drink, 12 Ounce (12 Cans). I grew up in the southeast and was used to seeing Cheerwine everywhere. But I recently moved to AZ and it's nowhere to be found, except for Cracker Barrel in glass bottles. It used to only be available on Amazon in larger numbers and a much higher price. I'm used to buying it like a fridge pack of Coke at the grocery store for $3. So I was overjoyed to see it on Amazon for a lot cheaper than it was and with free prime shipping. I will continue to buy it this way, and I encourage Amazon to continue this offering, maybe even work on lowering the cost further. But I am very happy with my purchase, and anyone who has not tried Cheerwine, buy this now!!
column9: Amazing for someone who grew up with it but now lives out of the region!

column8:
The nectar of the Carolinas is finally available to expats in a convenient (if understandably a tad pricey) way.

As sweet as a Tarheels victory. It makes love to your taste buds. As cozy as an Andy Griffith rerun. Goes well with pulled pork barbeque and as a flavor for home made ice cream.

Even better, this shipment is from the Cheerwine Centennial campaign so I get cans representing the different eras of its packaging.
column9: A taste of North Carolina - now available everywhere. Savor like your fans rushing the court after beating Duke.

column8: I am generally a Diet Dr Pepper drinker. I read about this soda, and decided to try it. It has a nice, light but clean cherry taste. I've read it compared to Diet Cherry Dr Pepper, but it is lighter and more clearly cherry flavored. While I wouldn't turn down one if offered, it isn't good enough to pay the cost of buying it on line.

column8: I first had Cheerwine two years ago from a local gas station that had it in stock for about a month. I never saw it again in the Pacific Northwest. Cheerwine doesn't even compare to Cherry Coke or Dr. Pepper; it's hands down the best cherry flavored pop that I've ever had! If a soft drink could be smooth, then Cheerwine is the epitome of smooth. It doesn't "wear you down" like Coke or Dr. Pepper, so to speak. Cheerwine is always nice, crisp, refreshing, and has a unique taste. The shipping was also good, even in January. There were no frozen, exploded, or broken cans. At most there were minor dents. Plus the cans arrived ice cold because of the winter! I would definitely consider buying again.

column8:
Tastes like summer to me. Used to go to summer camp in western Virginia. Haven't been to the east coast in 10 years. I do not drink soda often, i try to keep carbs low, so this stuff is a treat to me.

This review is for the product, not the price. I haven't bought it from Amazon, and think i can find it cheaper than $12 for 2L, especially since budget soda is 3L for 99 cents

column8: I discovered this on a trip to VT, and can't get it in stores in NY. I'm not a huge soda drinker, but I love this. It's super sweet with a nice cherry flavor. column8: Purchased this as I grew up with this southern soda in North Carolina and cannot get it in local stores in California. column8: I love this soda.  The unique flavor (not too sweet, not too sour) makes it better than other cherry flavored sodas you can find in the grocery store.  The first time I tried it was about 20 years ago after a relative brought some home from a trip to South Carolina.  Since I live in New Jersey this soda is nearly impossible to find.  I was excited to find it on Amazon.

column8:
You haven't actually had cheerwine yet. What's that? You've tried it before when you were in-or-around the North Carolina area? Well let me tell you a secret. ...Was there ice cream in it? NO?! Stop. Stop what you're doing right now. Put the keyboard down. And grab some vanilla ice cream. Scoop that stuff into your cheerwine soda right now. Stir it up, and allow your taste buds entry into heaven.

Seriously. This stuff is good. The soda is good on it's own. Tastes like a strong Cherry Dr. Pepper. But it enters a whole other realm when you add ice cream and make a cheerwine float. It will honestly change your life. An incredible mixture of deliciousness and perfectness. This stuff is incredible. It's found at a good price here from this seller, and can be shipped reasonably across the country for us native North Carolinians who have moved elsewhere. I loved this soda and will continue to purchase to have an endless supply of Cheerwine floats.
column9: With Ice Cream, it's the best thing I've ever tasted.

column8:
Always wanted to grab this stuff, given its reputation and my love of dumb novelty drinks; even the packaging invites you to taste the legend. Said legend is kind of like a cherry cola with the ratios reversed in favor of cherry, and if that doesn't sound terribly exciting, neither is the drink, although it is a fairly unique taste. It also fortunately avoids falling into the trap of tasting like cough syrup, unlike a lot of cherry-flavored things.

I went through it all, and fairly quickly, but my first experience with Cheerwine will still be my last, at least if I have to get it shipped to me again. I'm sure there'd be no end of people telling me that the version with real sugar is vastly superior, but I couldn't tell the difference between Pepsi's "throwback" offerings and its current incarnations, and I doubt this would prove much different. It was fun to try, though.
column9: It's nothing special, but it's different enough to try

column8: It is so, so hard to spend $11 on a 2-liter bottle of soda pop. Especially when they were 2/$1 at any Virginian Food Lion. But here in Illinois, this price is just a smidge better than my other option: $2 for a glass bottle. A lot of the time, the fun (and instant gratification of buying locally) makes the glass bottle worth it. It's still nice to have the 2-liter option, though.
column9: 5 stars for Cheerwine, 3 stars for the import price :(

Cheerwine is the best cherry pop!  Many people try to compare to Cherry Pepsi or Coke, but this is different!  Very different.  Cherry Pepsi and Coke start with Pepsi and Coke, then add cherry.  Cheerwine starts with cherry!  Not overwhelming flavor.  Right amount of fizz!

Love it!  Everyone should try it.  Make sure it is SUPER cold.  If it gets hot or flat, throw it out.  Fountain pop is preferred, then 2L bottle, then 20oz, then glass bottle, then can.  But beggars can't be choosy.
column11: ['Grocery & Gourmet Food', 'Beverages', 'Bottled Beverages, Water & Drink Mixes', 'Soft Drinks']
column12: ['Created in 1917 in Salisbury, North Carolina by a general store owner named L.D. Peeler, this singular soft drink with a hint of wild cherry and a bubbly effervescence became an immediate hit. Folks from all around the county came to LD\'s store to give it a try.\n\nSoon cold cases all over North Carolina were filled with the "Nectar of North Carolina." It was known to put a smile on everyone\'s lips who gave it a try, and the Legend was born.', 'Statements regarding dietary supplements have not been evaluated by the FDA and are not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease or health condition.']

column8: The cans ingredients are NOT THE SAME as the bottles. The bottles are made with cane sugar, the cans have high fructose corn syrup as the sweetener. So , if you are buying the cans thinking that they are made with sugar, the same as the bottles, they are not . Once again the sweetener in the cans are :"HIGH FRUCTOSE CORN SYRUP". Go To "cheerwine.com and look at the ingredients listed for the cans. How disappointing that such a good product would stoop so low as to put "CORN SYRUP" into ANY of it's products.
column9: NOT MADE WITH SUGAR/made with HIGH FRUCTOSE CORN SYRUP, is the sweetner....

column8:
When I first heard about this soft drink I was a bit skeptical I mean how could this be better than Cherry Cola? Being from Northern New England Ive never even heard of this drink and now I had a friend from North Carolina ranting and raving about how good this drink is. Well, needless to say my wife ordered some and when I tried it I was very impressed. First off you have to be a cherry lover to enjoy this delicious elixir and don't worry it doesnt taste like cherry cough syrup but it actually taste like real cherry juice only carbonated. I couldn't help but have a couple in a row one after the other. This will have your taste buds tingling for days and youll forget all about Cherry Cola and all those other syrupy imposters.
Note: This does not taste anything like Dr. Pepper so if youve heard it compared to Dr. Pepper I find that totally misleading since Cheer wine has much more flavor.
So order a case and have a Cherry good time.

column8: I was hoping it would be more on the Cherry 7up tip, but with more cherry flavor. I've lived on the west coast my whole life and wanted to try this for a very long time, but Cheerwine is not sold out west. I finally found a decent price and shipping so I thought I would give it a try. I can't say I will be disappointed if I never have it again, but I'm glad I tried it this time. While this may not be my personal choice my Dad loves it. I will continue to buy it for him as long as the price stays reasonable. It is great over vanilla ice cream as a Cheerwine float.
column9: Tastes like Cherry Dr. Pepper. Could use a little more cherry flavor imho.

column8: I fell in love with this when I lived in North Carolina in the 80's, and haven't had it since.  I noticed some in a store in NC when I was down for Christmas last year, and looked online for a source and, lo and behold, it was available on Amazon!.  The shipping cst was fairly prohibitive, but I just couldn't say no.  Nice cherry flavor with no syrupy aftertaste.
column9: pretty tasty treat from my past!

column8: The soda loses its carbonation too quickly like a cheap store brand generic soda.  Essentially the soda is a cherry flavored drink...not maraschino/grenadine cherry like other cherry flavored sodas or products with 'cherry' flavor added (i.e. Cherry Dr. Pepper, Cherry Coke)...but Cheerwine taste like real pitted cherries.  The soda has the darker red color like a real cherry, not the bright red syrup/food coloring look.  I like the real cherry favor idea behind the soda; however, you cannot finish a can or bottle without to going totally flat.  I assume they have to cut corners to complete with their massive corporation competitors.

column8: Cheerwine is a cherry flavored carbonated drink. The cherry flavor is light and not as powerful as one might expect. It's lack of intensity is the only reason I give it 3 stars. I am a full flavored, give me something to sink my teeth into, kind of drinker. However, despite my tendencies, I still purchase Cheerwine when lighter is what I am after. Extremely hot days, for example. Too much flavoring and sweetness can make me ill and Cheerwine is at its' best during those types of days. Being a North Carolina regional drink, it makes perfect sense. After all, hot balmy days can run from May through mid September there. For a spectacular combo, try Cheerwine with Red Velvet Cake for dessert. Now talk about cuisine, that combo is truly top notch. The tastes compliment each other in a way that produces a wonderful 6 star experience.

column8: We moved from NC to AZ a few years ago, and one of the biggest things my husband missed was his Cheerwine. I never looked to see if it could be shipped, because honestly, who ships soda? We were both really missing home today, on a whim, I went to the Cheerwine site. I think I'm still partially deaf from the hoopla that ensued when I saw that it could be delivered. People not from the south may not understand the draw of Cheerwine, but there is nothing else like it, and we've tried it all. It's not just cherry soda; it's how it's made, the taste of the water, the smells in the air that all flavor the ingredients in a way that can not be reproduced.

column8: I grew up with Cheerwine, and there is truly nothing like it.  I am not a big soda drinker, but when I do get a craving, Cheerwine is it.  I like that the cherry taste is mellow and that the carbonation isn't at strong as other sodas.  It isn't syrupy, either, the mix is just right.  When I lived in FL I really missed it.  The minute I would hit the NC border when I would visit home, I'd stop at the first convenience store and grab one.  This is just an example of the loyalty this drink inspires.  Once you have tried it, you'll be spoiled for anything else.
column9: A Flavor I Grew Up With

column8: The soda deserves a 5/5 just for it's wonderful taste. I find myself ordering Cheerwine from time to time just to taste the soda of my childhood. The only reason that I am rating this product so low is because of the incorrect information on the Amazon page. You are paying for 2 12 packs, not 4. I was more than happy to pay the listed price, + shipping, for 48 cans, but not for 24. Will buy from the company instead next time.

column8:
My parents moved to Salisbury, NC when I was 9 years old. We noticed immediately the ubiquitous advertisements for Cheerwine everywhere, from billboards on the side of the interstate to almost ancient Cheerwine paintings on the sides of some of the older historic buildings in town. And if the locals weren't drinking sweet tea they had a Cheerwine in their hands. And at the age of 9, after my first bottle, I understood why. The stuff is *good*. It's addictively good.

Cheerwine is a deep red/burgundy color and will stain your carpet, so don't drop any. As to how to describe the taste, saying it's "Cherry flavored soda" is not quite adequate. It's more like liquid cherry candy. It is very sweet, probably a lot sweeter than most soda drinkers are used to, and finishes on your palate extremely well. I tend to think it goes well with almost any food but find it complements pork BBQ best. And if you manage to get your mitts on the glass bottle Cheerwine be prepared for a really exuisite taste treat as it's manufactured with real cane sugar in lieu of corn syrup, and the difference is noticeable.

If Cheerwine has any one drawback it's that the stuff goes flat very fast. If you pop open a can make sure to drink it within an hour's time because flat Cheerwine is pretty wretched stuff (in the same way that cold black coffee is). This is one of the reasons I almost never get the 2-liter bottle of the stuff unless I'm at a social gathering and it's guaranteed to go within a short amount of time. If you can find it, the Cheerwine ice cream (either homemade, a perennial favorite at church picnics, or the Cheerwine Company type you can buy at the store, also good) is also delicious. It's a unique soda that I cannot recommend highly enough.

Note: This review written with a 20 oz. ice cold Cheerwine by the keyboard. :)

column8:
Cheerwine is a regional soda from North Carolina, that has expanded into 12 other southeast states in the last 8 years. Started in 1917, Cheerwine was first formulated in the basement of L. D. Peeler's wholesale grocery store. Created during prohibition when it was common to name sodas after liquors. The owner added a new cherry flavor syrup to his previous soda and cheerwine was born. Believe it or his great grandsons still run the company.
The bergundy red soft drink has a nice mellow cherry flavor, and the color is really a pretty burgundy color, almost like wine. It is more subtle and seems less sweet on the palate than the grocery store house brands of cherry soda. No aftertaste or bite. There is also a diet version. They are also sold locally in bottles as well as the cans you see here. It is easy to see why the locals in North Carolina rave about this "Nectar of the Carolinas". Another hard to find drink from this company is "Cool Moon", a citrus flavored pop.

column8:
Gustaf's Wine Gums have all the things I like about Gummis and none of what I don't.

I like fruit flavors and chewy snacks. Wine gums are chewy and they have a fruit flavor that is not quite as sweet as Gummi snacks.

I don't care for things that make my fingers sticky. Wine Gums have a texture like Swedish Fish.

column8:
I have been a frequent buyer from Amazon since 1999 and this, as I recall, is the first item that I have ever returned.
The item description(s) could hardly be more confusing if they tried.
The horrible changed recipe candies that arrived are NOT labeled "NEW RECIPE".
The original candies that almost everyone loves ARE labeled "NEW RECIPE".
Both versions say Item number 31814. What could possibly go wrong?

What went wrong is that the new concoction is terrible.
I suspect that Amazon's rating of 3.9 out of 5 has not separated reviews of the original recipe from changed recipe that is receiving a lot of complaints.
I am also not sure what flavor of arithmetic they are using to arrive at this figure.

The original recipe says on the label (which is on both the box and each package):
Gustaf's NEW RECIPE
WINE GUMS
ITEM #31814
The candies are translucent, with subdued colors and delicious.

The recently changed recipe says on the label (which was on the box only):
Gustaf's Item nr: 31814
WINE GUMS
The new attempts are opaque with bright unnatural colors and very undelicous.

Why the Item numbers on both is 31814 shall remain a mystery to me.

I, and I'm sure many others, would like to have a little better clarification as to which product we are ordering.
Most of us did not realize there were even 2 products to chose from.
Best would be to not sell the new formula at all.
Of the many reviews I read, certainly not all 222, I did not see one that said,
"I like the new ones even better." Many said, "I will never order these again!"
However, I am going to make one more attempt to order the original Gustaf's NEW RECIPE WINE GUMS.

If that is not possible, I'm afraid Amazon will enjoy many more happy returns.

column8:
Terrible gummy. I used to enjoy this product, but the formula has been changed and is now pretty bad. The new package saws "New recipe." It was apparently changed to be gluten free. These are not as good as many gummy candies available at most supermarkets; gummy worms, or Swedish fish.

I want to ask for a refund, but I won't because it's food. One should not return food items. I feel cheated because I ordered the same product I used to, but I was delivered a different product. I now see that the old product is available under a different name. I won't be ordering it though, as I feel cheated by the company. If they were releasing a new product they should have given the new product a new name instead of renaming the old product.

column8:
I would like to add my comments because I have been purchasing these for years.

When I first found Gustaf's wine gums about 5 or 6 years ago they were the best gummy candy that i had ever had. I quickly adopted a tradition of giving packs of them to family members as Christmas gifts and they were universally loved. My personal favorite has always been the currant flavored one. The texture was soft but a bit chewy and the flavors were great and not quite as sweet most other gummy offerings.

Then sometime within the past two years they did change the recipe and to my dismay the change was for the worst. So what changed?  Well the flavors seem to be pretty close to the originals, although I must admit that non from the original bags survived so this was not a side by side comparison.. but the big thing for me was that the texture was completely different. The "new recipe" is tougher to chew. That does not sound so bad  but it does leave me wondering why they would change something so good. The shapes changed too but that did not bother me. Anyway the change sent me on a search for a better option so I started buying every brand wine gum that I could find.

The results of this search left me wanting. These Gustaf's Wine Gums are still the best that i can find which is why a feel obligated to give them four stars and I still purchase them, enjoy them and give them as gifts but inevitably someone who receives them asks why they are not the same and I regret to tell them that "I don't know". I will come back to this review and change it to five stars if any of my future purchases seem to go back to that original recipe but for now I just chew a little harder.

column8: Having spent some time living in England my family and I became very familiar with this product. We were delighted to find it available through Amazon. I have been ordering them for several years, always with satisfaction UNTIL the last batch ordered February 2015. What has Gustav's done to them? The bag says new recipe and we are not happy with their decisions in making this new version. It is not the same consistency nor is the flavor what it was. It would have been nice to know there was a new formula BEFORE I ordered them. There is no indication on the site or the description of the product to alert anyone to the change. The change is NOT for the better and my family and I will not be ordering them again. Why they tampered with a successful product is beyond me.

Gone are the delicious fruit flavors, the nice and chewy experience, and what's worse the entire lot seems to taste the same. I rec'd a refund and will never purchase these again.

column8: Firstly, I rarely write reviews but this needed saying to anyone thinking of ordering this candy.  At one time, Gustav's wine gums were the only ones that could even come close to Maynard's.  We got addicted to the Maynard wine gums on our many trips to England visiting family.  We tried the Gustav wine gums some time ago as they were quite a bit cheaper than the increasingly more expensive ones from Maynard.  They were quite good then, but they have now apparently changed the formula and they would not be worth the calories if they were free!  What were these people thinking unless it was a lesson in how to take a good product and make it into something vile.

column8: What happened! My heart is genuinely heavy with the knowledge that Gustaf's has changed their recipe right under the noses of their loyal customers. I have been buying Gustaf's brand wine gums for years, but I will never buy another ounce of this new recipe. The colors are wrong, the shapes are wrong, the flavors are as far from the old recipe as you can get, and the experience is gone. The new recipe is such a stark deviation from the traditional wine gum flavor profile. The highest insult is that these new gums taste like a shoddy American candy now. What a loss.

column8:
I have been a long time buyer of Gustaf's wine gums -they are a family favorite. I would have nothing but great things to say about them and give them a 5 star rating until recently. On my last order, I was greeted with a " NEW RECIPE" banner on the package - unfortunately, in my opinion, and the opinion of the rest of the family, the new recipe falls far short of the old one. They are still wine gums, and as such, so very worthwhile, and I truly never met a wine gum I didn't like, but why change something that was truly delicious? The new colors are muted, and so is the taste.
Gustaf's - please bring back your old recipe. Like "New Coke", not everything needs to be redone.

column8:
I should start my review, by stating that I spent three years in Germany near Bohn (Ramstein AFB) so I had many opportunities to sample European candies and chocolates (Belgium chocolate is the worlds best!).
So after more than 2 decades back stateside I had a craving for the real gummies I enjoyed in Germany. I was delighted to find I could ordered Haribo products from Amazon, and was thrilled when the product arrived stating it was made in Spain,  But after ordering more over of a few years, I wanted something different.  I read several reviews (back in 2012) about Gustaf's Wine gums. I ordered the 3 pack from Amazon,  and knew that I would never needed to order Haribo Gummy Bears again!  The texture the flavors and the large size  gums made them an instant favorite and I quickly shared them with friends and co-workers trying to convince them to stop eating the American Haribo knockoffs (which sadly don't even taste as good as their European cousins). Then proceeded to order more every six months or so.
So you might be wandering since I have waxed so fondly over Gustafs wine gums why have I gave the product only one star?
Good question, and the answer is the product label that consumers world wide have come to hate "New and Improved".  So what has changed in the new and improved wine gums? Everything but the shapes and the alcohol names molded into the shapes. First the gums are smaller, I could forgive this, but the wonderful fruity flavors I came to adore, are gone!  All of the gums now taste the same! Worst yet the gums tasted waxy. If I wanted crappy wax flavored candy I would just have bought the inferior American made gummies or Mike & Ikes!
Even worse two of the three bags tasted stale, I wasn't sure if this was due to air leaks in the bags, or the manufactures poor quality control.  So sadly unless Gustafs goes back to its old formula (like Coke did with the "new coke" fiasco, I will never buy these third rate candies again!  Anyone suggest a better Wine Gum that comes in similar size bags?
column9: Sometimes the old phrase is right; if it ain't broke don't fix it! Or why the label of " New & improved" makes me cringe

column8:
AAAKKKKKKKK!!!  SWITCHEROO!  Not good anymore!!!
I have been ordering (many!) boxes of these for years and loved them (and always ran out quickly)....I re-ordered last week (b/c I couldn't wait for next subscription) and got shipment this week.  I was shocked to discover they looked different,  and then when I ate a few, I found out that they tasted awful (esp compared to prior versions).  I have literally tried all kinds of wine gums and had after much trial and error discovered that these (in the past) were a great flavorful option and the size/price were a good value, plus being on amazon, I could easily get them.

But apparently they changed the recipe and tried to slip them right in there thinking no one would notice---there were some smaller words on the label that said "new recipe" that I only saw after tasting them and wondering what I was eating that I looked at the package--I definitely noticed.  I swear, I wish manufacturers would just stay with their product....just like "new coke" sometimes "new" isn't the way to go and it can make a lot of loyal customers very mad (note to the exec team at Gustaf's:  read the case studies on that fiasco).  I cannot figure why they would change something that a lot of people enjoyed and was well-reviewed as is.

These 'new' wine gums are just awful....they have minimal flavor, and even those flavors are weird and not identifiable. The texture has also changed--the pieces are much smaller and more dense--almost rubbery, whereas before they were thicker and smoother--a very unique texture that I personally preferred over others.  Plus, the price of the box has risen substantially.  No clue why they changed things, but they've lost me as a customer.  I can only hope that I can get a refund of this order from amazon because I'm not able to bring myself to eat them and waste the calories.  I'm so frustrated with Gustaf's.......
column9: AAAKKKK---Buyer Beware!  They changed the 'recipe' and these are horrible now!

column8:
There are about 6 celiac folks in the world, so let's make EVERYTHING gluten free!

Keep your reformulated nonsense.

We used to really love these things. They say the "Gumbilees" are the old wine gums. Well fine, make them the price they used to be and I'll buy those. But they're way more expensive, and I'm not interested in your reformulated "gluten-free" garbage. Watch your customer base DROP.

Bye

By the way, this was originally posted as a 5 star review. We loved these things! I had to come back and change it later, just like Gustaf's came back and changed this product...much for the worse.

column8: I am a lifelong Maynards fan (born and raised in UK, now resident in US), but have had trouble finding a local supplier - Maynards are expensive in the US, and they lose their freshness if they are in storage too long. I tried Gustaf's because you get so many in one order, and most of the reviews were positive. Sadly, these are nothing like Maynards in terms of either taste or consistency. They have a much sharper and also narrower range of tastes (most of them taste like sour apples, no matter what the color), and they are much chewier than Maynards. In all, a huge disappointment, and if you like Maynards it is unlikely you'll like these. I have two kids and have to hide the Maynards away from them, and ration the supplies. Not so with Gustaf's - we now have 2 and a half packs of them lying mainly ignored in the pantry.

column8:
First, I've bought many of these three packs of Gustaf Wine Gums.  They are delicious, found them when I was in England/Germany 30 years ago.  I overdose on the 2.2 pound bags, but that's life.  No problems at all, 10 stars for the wine gums.

ONE STAR for Amazon for cancelling Subscribe and Save where a 3-pack was ~$17, now the price has almost doubled to over $30 and no Subscribe and Save.

I did find the three packs for ~20 at the URL below.  Earn their business and maybe Amazon will learn.

[...]

column8: I bought these wine gums 9 times since Oct. 2012. the first 8 times I was charged $20.31 the last time I bought them they were $25.21, almost a five dollar increase , but I really like these candies, they are delicious. I went to order another box and I saw $27 and change on the site, I thought ''wow these things are going up like crazy''. Then I clicked on the item and saw the price was almost double of what I was paying $39.95.  I've noticed that a lot of products on Amazon have raised their prices. One item  I was reviewing was $12.49 while I was reading about it, by the time I added it to my cart it was $12.99. This is really annoying. Now I am hooked on these wine gums but I am reluctant to pay twice the price for them. I will see how long I can hold off without them.

The flavor is really good, they are a little soft right out of the bag, but if you leave it open for a few days they harden up quite nicely.

column8:
I have always been a fan of Bassett Wine Gums but they were not available on Amazon, so I decided to give these a try.  Although not as good as Bassett's, these wine gums are very good.  I was impressed with how quickly they arrived (less than a week), as well as the quantity (three large bags).

I tried a few at first but they disappointed me a little.  Didn't seem chewy enough.  However, after I put them in the refrigerator for a few hours, I tried them again.  Wow!  They were a knock-out and I found that I couldn't stop eating the things.  It got to a point where I was eating about 50 in a single sitting -- night after night.  Not exactly a healthy habit.  My son-in-law loves them, too, so I plan on sharing any future purchases with him in order to preserve my waistline.

I recommend this product if you are in the mood for a treat -- maybe you can control your wine gum consumption better than I can.

column8: I truly believe that Gummi is the 5th food group and I typically order candy in 5 lb bags for myself and eat about 1lb a week.  I am a total candy junkie. Swedish Fish, German Raspberries, Fruit Slices, and the rest.  But these wine gums are the BOMB!  Seriously if you have never had them you just need to order some and experience the sublime taste and texture of these.  There are about 5 other brands of wine gums out there but these are the ones you are looking for.  Everyone I've introduced to these gems have had a similar reaction: "What are these? They are amazing".  But I have to caution you: they are very addicting.

column8:
These were truly excellent and you really get a ton of them for the price.  These were the first winegums I have tried and like them way better then any other gummys.  Now I need to try more of them and just yesterday ordered from amazon the Haribo and Maynards winegums to compare.  I will try and update this review after I have had both.

UPDATE: Haribo Wine Gums just arrived.. what a disappointment.  Just over-sized Haribo gummy bears... same way too soft texture.  Flavors are boring also.
UPDATE: Maynards Wines Gums just arrived... Also disappointing... Some were firm.. some were soft.. flavors were pretty strange.  Looks like Gustaf's is the winner for now... and still the best deal by far.

column8: They are DELICIOUS, much firmer than gummibears...almost like good caramels that don't stick to your teeth. The candies themselves are large--more like two of the winegums I am used to--and not overly sweet. The (3) 2.2 lb assortment from Amazon is a great bargain as well (especially on their S&S plan), much less than I have paid elsewhere, even in Canada where winegums are a bit more of a staple in stores. BUT, so few of my favorite purple candies--one bag had only one! I understand that blackcurrant flavoring is more expensive than orange, lemon, lime, etc. but I'd be willing to pay a bit more if the distribution was fairer. Lots of the citrus flavors, and plenty of red for my taste, but the purple is the real deal. I'm keeping my subscription as the kids like the other flavors, but if Gustaf's ever wants to sell me a bag of the purples, I'm all over it!

column8: I found this candy first in a candy shop in Seaside, Oregon.  They were the closest thing to the gummie candy I found in a drug store in Austria that I had found.  Love them!  But I thought I wasn't going to be able to find them again short of shipping them cross country from Oregon.  Then I found them on Amazon and I am a happy woman!  The flavors are so rich and they are not slimy like gummie bears and they don't stick in your teeth.  I want others to try them so Amazon continues to carry them but I don't want too many people to order them and cause them to be out of stock when I want them!  Really really good.

column8:
First, I had not tried Wine Gums before these, so I cannot compare them to other brands of Wine Gums.  However, I can compare them to similar style gummy candy, such as Swedish Fish.  Comparatively, these Wine Gums are chewier, more flavorful & more tart.  The flavors are very distinct, and delicious.  Yes, these are definitely sweet candies, but the intense fruit flavor and tartness make them much more enjoyable and tasty than Swedish Fish or gummy bears.
I would highly recommend trying these if you are a fan of gummy bears or Swedish Fish.

column8:
Not as sweet as Haribi, Brach's, Trolli's.  nice and chewy.  Not jelly textured like gummi bears. Mild tartness.  Dark purple ones are flavored like black currant.  Yellow is lemon flavored, orange is orange flavored,.  I would say if you like chewy, lightly flavored, not too sweet, large candy, en this is for you.
Two bags later, I think these are the best gummi-type candy hands-down, okay.  No more Haribo or any other gummi. Gustav wine gums all they way!

column8: I ate Maynard's Wine Gums while in England many moons ago and enjoyed them, so I thought I'd try this Dutch brand.  I guess my tastes have changed or something, because I didn't like these as much as those I sampled years ago.  The flavors seem blander.  I actually prefer Jujyfruits.  I guess I am an uncouth American who prefers punched-up fruity flavors to these European flavors.  The gums come in various shapes like diamonds, circles, and rectangles.  They are labeled with names like cider, port, rum, and cognac.  The consistency is good, chewy, and soft.  They don't stick to your teeth, not even dental work.  They are each about the size of a quarter.  Vegans and vegetarians should note that, although the description says they don't contain gelatin, the ingredients list says they do.  I wouldn't order these again, because the flavors are so different from what I currently seek.  If you enjoy these, you get a huge amount delivered.  Frankly, I am going to donate the two unopened bags to a food bank, because I don't see myself eating them.

column8:
I grew up with Wine Gummies but not with Gustaf's.
Gustaf's are large.
They are chewy.
3 Pounds give you A LOT of large, chewy gummies.
I grew up with Haribo.
For anybody looking for the taste and consistency of Haribo - Gustaf's is not it.
But try them. They are not better and not worse, just different.

column8: Let's just say that these have spoiled me and made me not want any other gummies. They just do not compare! The flavors and texture are so much better than typical gummy candies, and the size of each piece is perfect. They are not sticky, even when in warm temperatures. My favorites are the purple and the white/clear ones, but all of them are really good. Anyone with whom I've shared these wine gums immediately love them, too. I have to limit myself to a few at a time, because they are so delicious and so addictive! If you are a fan of gummy candy, you should try these. You will not regret spending the money for this treat.

column8: Funny, how one of the previous reviews is about an American who learned to eat wine gums while living in Denmark. Well, I was born and raised in Denmark and only moved to the US a little over a year ago. Since then, I have tried various wine gums I have picked up in the super market, and well, it is just not the same. But I now tried Gustaf's wine gums and they are wonderful! Compared to the well known Bassets wine gums, I think Gustafs wine gums have much more flavor. They also seem a little softer and although I prefer the slightly harder Bassets, the advantage is that they won't make your jaws hurt.

column8: ...being a "gummy" expert, Gustaf's Wine Gums are the best!  They have a unique texture because they are made with a totally different base than other gummies- they are starch based rather than the American gelatin based product.  The flavor is also very different and appeals to the adult taste - they really do have the hint of wine flavor not the common fruit sweetness.  Heads and shoulders better than Maynard's - my old standby!  Denmark you have surpassed all other similar European and American products.  I have had them on auto-deliver for several years and they are definitely worth the price!!!

column8:
The Cons:  I received three bags of wine gums in a plain brown cardboard box. None of the packaging had any identifying labels--not the manufacturer, not the ingredients, nothing. Just three clear cellophane bags. One of the bags had broken open, and a good third of the gummies were loose in the box. Undaunted, I sampled some of the spilled candy and Did Not Die.

The Pros:  These have to be the absolute best gummies I have ever tasted, bar none. They definitely resemble the candies in the Amazon picture, so I assume they ARE the Gustaf's brand. The flavors are delicious and unique, unlike many of the more kid-centric candies on the market. They are not for the weak of teeth, however, possessing a very persistent but satisfying chewiness. I love all of the flavors, although I cannot necessarily identify them. (Pear! There's definitely pear!)

The Verdict:  I'd give these five stars were it not for the packaging issues. If you're willing to take your life in your hands by eating questionably identifiable gummies, these are definitely worth the money. I say, go for it!

These Wine Gums kick butt!  Flavor-wise they are much better than just about any gummi bear (except maybe Haribo Gold Bears), and remind me a little bit of these Katje gummis we used to get in German class in High School.  Let me just say I'm lovin' it.

They are a bit firmer than gummi bears, but do not stick to your teeth like Dots or Jujubes.  Highly recommended confection.

column8:
I usually don't write reviews but here I feel the need:
In general Bassett's wine gums are my favorite, but I cannot find them in the US.  I was reluctant to try something different and be disappointed.
I decided to try Gustaf's wine gums and Now they are my favorite.

WOW really good wine gums, consistent in size, taste, and freshness.

Highly recommended!

Maynards are expensive but I have tried less expensive brands but they are never as good....TILL NOW....I agree with the other reviews. THESE WINE GUMS ARE EXCELLENT. I could not believe the reviewers indicating that these are better than Maynards but I do now. Couldn't be happier. Much better price and great flavor......YAY

column8:
and to a lesser extent the white ones.  The orange, red, green, and yellow are some of the best wine gum flavors I have eaten.  But the purple ones are supposed to be that strong almost border-line "tastes so bad its good can I have another" black currant flavor.  The Gutaf's ones are simply sweet with no discernable flavor.  So sad because one feels that a company that could do such an outstanding job with the other flavors, could do so much better. One caveat:  the white ones are, also, without discernable flavor, however, no respectable wine gum eater really expects too much of them, anyway.  Yes, it is the purple ones that will break your heart.

And should you, actually, like the purple and white ones, I have three bags of rejects I could fish out of the trash for you.

column8:
The texture and chewiness of these Winegums is just like the real deal.  They're not too soft like many of the imitation Winegums tend to be, so in that aspect, they're close to perfect.  However, the flavor is not the same, that's why I can't give them 5 stars.  These simply don't taste as good as the Maynard's, Bassett's, or some of the other kinds that can be found at European candy stores.

The price on these is so incredibly fair that I had to give them 4 stars.  Also, once you've eaten a few of them and you overcome the initial expectations, the flavor actually begins to improve and they can be enjoyed quite vividly.  I love eating these while studying for my exams.

I recommend them as a good alternative for the thrifty Winegums lover who is stuck in the USA and doesn't want to pay $50 on shipping to get the originals from Europe.

column8:
Wine Gums are my favorite candy. I simply can't get enough, especially of the Bassett's Wine Gums. When I visited family in Denmark this summer, I brought back 9 kilos of the stuff. Unfortunately, Bassett's are impossible to find in California, so I scoured the internet in search of good Wine Gums and found these.

Let me tell you, these are an EXCELLENT alternative to the Bassett's brand. They aren't exactly the same, so not as good, but they are excellent in their own right. I highly recommend these to anyone who is a Wine Gums fan. You will not be disappointed.

column8:
Born and raised in America, I had no idea what I was missing until living in Denmark and discovering wine gums.  Since returning to the states 10 years ago I have done my best to find the same brand that I would buy there.  The search continues but my first order of Gustaf's wine gums arrived today and I just may give up the search.  These are excellent wine gums:  tangy, tart, chewy--just about perfect.  Plus, they are noticeably larger than the wine gums I was used to in Europe.  If you like gummy candy it doesn't get any better than this.  Sorry gummy bears, but it's true.
Update:  While the product itself is great, I am very unhappy to see how much the price has increased on these in the last few months.  The subscribe and save option was taken away and the price nearly doubled.  I really love the product, but I can live without it at this price.

column8: I ordered the wine gummies because I remembered loving them as a child, and their intense flavor seemed sealed in my tastebud memory... The shipment included three huge bags of the candy (too few of the black/purple and red ones, IMO--seriously disproportioned toward the white and yellow), and the candy is good. The flavor is almost as I remember--somehow I thikn that childhood gave the candy an extra 'oomph' which this experience now, in adulthood did not share... But, these are still very good gummies, excellent consistency--not too sticky, not too soft. I've shared some (it is a LOT of candy) with others, who loved them as well. I recommend this purchase if you love gummies and want a change from the boring bears...
column9: Delicious, plentiful, almost as good as I remember.

column8:
I am a bit of a Wine Gum snob and rely on relatives in Holland to regularly refill my supplies.  I recently had a dry spell and decided to buy these Gustaf's from Amazon out of desperation.

They are excellent Wine Gums.  They are perhaps a bit chewier and the flavors are a bit stronger than my favorites but only by a small margin.

I will be savoring these until my Dutch supplier comes for a visit in a few weeks!

column8: I have always enjoyed wine gums. I am from Canada where they are widely available and I always brought home a few kilos of Maynards to last me through the time to my next visit. On a whim, I searched Amazon and noted these well-rated wine gums and decided to give them a try. They are excellent! Different in flavor and texture than Maynard's but I find them better. The flavors are more distinct and intense. I am so thrilled! I hope Amazon keeps these on the stock list for a long time. As other have mentioned, there is no alcohol in these candies. There is no fat either, and comparatively low sugar levels. Enjoy them, if you have been looking for wine gums, these are it, and a great buy to boot!!!

column8:
Gustaf's Wine Gums have all the things I like about Gummis and none of what I don't.

I like fruit flavors and chewy snacks. Wine gums are chewy and they have a fruit flavor that is not quite as sweet as Gummi snacks.

I don't care for things that make my fingers sticky. Wine Gums have a texture like Swedish Fish.

column8:
I have been a frequent buyer from Amazon since 1999 and this, as I recall, is the first item that I have ever returned.
The item description(s) could hardly be more confusing if they tried.
The horrible changed recipe candies that arrived are NOT labeled "NEW RECIPE".
The original candies that almost everyone loves ARE labeled "NEW RECIPE".
Both versions say Item number 31814. What could possibly go wrong?

What went wrong is that the new concoction is terrible.
I suspect that Amazon's rating of 3.9 out of 5 has not separated reviews of the original recipe from changed recipe that is receiving a lot of complaints.
I am also not sure what flavor of arithmetic they are using to arrive at this figure.

The original recipe says on the label (which is on both the box and each package):
Gustaf's NEW RECIPE
WINE GUMS
ITEM #31814
The candies are translucent, with subdued colors and delicious.

The recently changed recipe says on the label (which was on the box only):
Gustaf's Item nr: 31814
WINE GUMS
The new attempts are opaque with bright unnatural colors and very undelicous.

Why the Item numbers on both is 31814 shall remain a mystery to me.

I, and I'm sure many others, would like to have a little better clarification as to which product we are ordering.
Most of us did not realize there were even 2 products to chose from.
Best would be to not sell the new formula at all.
Of the many reviews I read, certainly not all 222, I did not see one that said,
"I like the new ones even better." Many said, "I will never order these again!"
However, I am going to make one more attempt to order the original Gustaf's NEW RECIPE WINE GUMS.

If that is not possible, I'm afraid Amazon will enjoy many more happy returns.

column8:
Terrible gummy. I used to enjoy this product, but the formula has been changed and is now pretty bad. The new package saws "New recipe." It was apparently changed to be gluten free. These are not as good as many gummy candies available at most supermarkets; gummy worms, or Swedish fish.

I want to ask for a refund, but I won't because it's food. One should not return food items. I feel cheated because I ordered the same product I used to, but I was delivered a different product. I now see that the old product is available under a different name. I won't be ordering it though, as I feel cheated by the company. If they were releasing a new product they should have given the new product a new name instead of renaming the old product.

column8:
I would like to add my comments because I have been purchasing these for years.

When I first found Gustaf's wine gums about 5 or 6 years ago they were the best gummy candy that i had ever had. I quickly adopted a tradition of giving packs of them to family members as Christmas gifts and they were universally loved. My personal favorite has always been the currant flavored one. The texture was soft but a bit chewy and the flavors were great and not quite as sweet most other gummy offerings.

Then sometime within the past two years they did change the recipe and to my dismay the change was for the worst. So what changed?  Well the flavors seem to be pretty close to the originals, although I must admit that non from the original bags survived so this was not a side by side comparison.. but the big thing for me was that the texture was completely different. The "new recipe" is tougher to chew. That does not sound so bad  but it does leave me wondering why they would change something so good. The shapes changed too but that did not bother me. Anyway the change sent me on a search for a better option so I started buying every brand wine gum that I could find.

The results of this search left me wanting. These Gustaf's Wine Gums are still the best that i can find which is why a feel obligated to give them four stars and I still purchase them, enjoy them and give them as gifts but inevitably someone who receives them asks why they are not the same and I regret to tell them that "I don't know". I will come back to this review and change it to five stars if any of my future purchases seem to go back to that original recipe but for now I just chew a little harder.

column8: Having spent some time living in England my family and I became very familiar with this product. We were delighted to find it available through Amazon. I have been ordering them for several years, always with satisfaction UNTIL the last batch ordered February 2015. What has Gustav's done to them? The bag says new recipe and we are not happy with their decisions in making this new version. It is not the same consistency nor is the flavor what it was. It would have been nice to know there was a new formula BEFORE I ordered them. There is no indication on the site or the description of the product to alert anyone to the change. The change is NOT for the better and my family and I will not be ordering them again. Why they tampered with a successful product is beyond me.

column8: Haribro has nothing on gustafs. These wine gums are like America's gummy bears but the taste and texture couldn't compare. These wine gums are juicy, the flavors are amazing and the texture is perfectly tough. Actual food ingredients are used in place of dyes. I give them a 5/5.

column8: I ordered these recently and when the shipment arrived the package on the wine gums said 'New Recipe'. It's new all right and the taste is AWFUL!!! Something like a vegetable taste of lettuce, celery and cabbage which almost made me sick. That plus the 'new' gums are about half the size of the old ones and are FAR more difficult to chew. Gone are the delicious fruit flavors, the nice and chewy experience, and what's worse the entire lot seems to taste the same. I rec'd a refund and will never purchase these again.

column8: Firstly, I rarely write reviews but this needed saying to anyone thinking of ordering this candy.  At one time, Gustav's wine gums were the only ones that could even come close to Maynard's.  We got addicted to the Maynard wine gums on our many trips to England visiting family.  We tried the Gustav wine gums some time ago as they were quite a bit cheaper than the increasingly more expensive ones from Maynard.  They were quite good then, but they have now apparently changed the formula and they would not be worth the calories if they were free!  What were these people thinking unless it was a lesson in how to take a good product and make it into something vile.

column8: What happened! My heart is genuinely heavy with the knowledge that Gustaf's has changed their recipe right under the noses of their loyal customers. I have been buying Gustaf's brand wine gums for years, but I will never buy another ounce of this new recipe. The colors are wrong, the shapes are wrong, the flavors are as far from the old recipe as you can get, and the experience is gone. The new recipe is such a stark deviation from the traditional wine gum flavor profile. The highest insult is that these new gums taste like a shoddy American candy now. What a loss.

column8:
I have been a long time buyer of Gustaf's wine gums -they are a family favorite. I would have nothing but great things to say about them and give them a 5 star rating until recently. On my last order, I was greeted with a " NEW RECIPE" banner on the package - unfortunately, in my opinion, and the opinion of the rest of the family, the new recipe falls far short of the old one. They are still wine gums, and as such, so very worthwhile, and I truly never met a wine gum I didn't like, but why change something that was truly delicious? The new colors are muted, and so is the taste.
Gustaf's - please bring back your old recipe. Like "New Coke", not everything needs to be redone.

column8:
I should start my review, by stating that I spent three years in Germany near Bohn (Ramstein AFB) so I had many opportunities to sample European candies and chocolates (Belgium chocolate is the worlds best!).
So after more than 2 decades back stateside I had a craving for the real gummies I enjoyed in Germany. I was delighted to find I could ordered Haribo products from Amazon, and was thrilled when the product arrived stating it was made in Spain,  But after ordering more over of a few years, I wanted something different.  I read several reviews (back in 2012) about Gustaf's Wine gums. I ordered the 3 pack from Amazon,  and knew that I would never needed to order Haribo Gummy Bears again!  The texture the flavors and the large size  gums made them an instant favorite and I quickly shared them with friends and co-workers trying to convince them to stop eating the American Haribo knockoffs (which sadly don't even taste as good as their European cousins). Then proceeded to order more every six months or so.
So you might be wandering since I have waxed so fondly over Gustafs wine gums why have I gave the product only one star?
Good question, and the answer is the product label that consumers world wide have come to hate "New and Improved".  So what has changed in the new and improved wine gums? Everything but the shapes and the alcohol names molded into the shapes. First the gums are smaller, I could forgive this, but the wonderful fruity flavors I came to adore, are gone!  All of the gums now taste the same! Worst yet the gums tasted waxy. If I wanted crappy wax flavored candy I would just have bought the inferior American made gummies or Mike & Ikes!
Even worse two of the three bags tasted stale, I wasn't sure if this was due to air leaks in the bags, or the manufactures poor quality control.  So sadly unless Gustafs goes back to its old formula (like Coke did with the "new coke" fiasco, I will never buy these third rate candies again!  Anyone suggest a better Wine Gum that comes in similar size bags?
column9: Sometimes the old phrase is right; if it ain't broke don't fix it! Or why the label of " New & improved" makes me cringe

column8:
Lovers of Gustaf's Wine Gums will be disappointed to receive this product with a "New Recipe!" marking on the packages.

The new product is nothing like the traditional wine gums.  Gone are the deep, complex fruit flavors, replaced by overly-sweet and cheap tasting candies.  This will be my last order.

What's more annoying than the "new recipe?"  The fact that they didn't advertise / communicate the change to buyers!  Bad marketing...

column8:
AAAKKKKKKKK!!!  SWITCHEROO!  Not good anymore!!!
I have been ordering (many!) boxes of these for years and loved them (and always ran out quickly)....I re-ordered last week (b/c I couldn't wait for next subscription) and got shipment this week.  I was shocked to discover they looked different,  and then when I ate a few, I found out that they tasted awful (esp compared to prior versions).  I have literally tried all kinds of wine gums and had after much trial and error discovered that these (in the past) were a great flavorful option and the size/price were a good value, plus being on amazon, I could easily get them.

But apparently they changed the recipe and tried to slip them right in there thinking no one would notice---there were some smaller words on the label that said "new recipe" that I only saw after tasting them and wondering what I was eating that I looked at the package--I definitely noticed.  I swear, I wish manufacturers would just stay with their product....just like "new coke" sometimes "new" isn't the way to go and it can make a lot of loyal customers very mad (note to the exec team at Gustaf's:  read the case studies on that fiasco).  I cannot figure why they would change something that a lot of people enjoyed and was well-reviewed as is.

These 'new' wine gums are just awful....they have minimal flavor, and even those flavors are weird and not identifiable. The texture has also changed--the pieces are much smaller and more dense--almost rubbery, whereas before they were thicker and smoother--a very unique texture that I personally preferred over others.  Plus, the price of the box has risen substantially.  No clue why they changed things, but they've lost me as a customer.  I can only hope that I can get a refund of this order from amazon because I'm not able to bring myself to eat them and waste the calories.  I'm so frustrated with Gustaf's.......
column9: AAAKKKK---Buyer Beware!  They changed the 'recipe' and these are horrible now!

column8: Previous orders of this product from this vendor were excellent, but this set of three must have been on the shelf for a long time, causing the gummies to lose their soft texture and pick up a detectable bitter taste I would describe as resulting from absorbing off-gas from the packaging. column8:
There are about 6 celiac folks in the world, so let's make EVERYTHING gluten free!

Keep your reformulated nonsense.

We used to really love these things. They say the "Gumbilees" are the old wine gums. Well fine, make them the price they used to be and I'll buy those. But they're way more expensive, and I'm not interested in your reformulated "gluten-free" garbage. Watch your customer base DROP.

Bye

By the way, this was originally posted as a 5 star review. We loved these things! I had to come back and change it later, just like Gustaf's came back and changed this product...much for the worse.

column8: I am a lifelong Maynards fan (born and raised in UK, now resident in US), but have had trouble finding a local supplier - Maynards are expensive in the US, and they lose their freshness if they are in storage too long. I tried Gustaf's because you get so many in one order, and most of the reviews were positive. Sadly, these are nothing like Maynards in terms of either taste or consistency. They have a much sharper and also narrower range of tastes (most of them taste like sour apples, no matter what the color), and they are much chewier than Maynards. In all, a huge disappointment, and if you like Maynards it is unlikely you'll like these. I have two kids and have to hide the Maynards away from them, and ration the supplies. Not so with Gustaf's - we now have 2 and a half packs of them lying mainly ignored in the pantry.

ONE STAR for Amazon for cancelling Subscribe and Save where a 3-pack was ~$17, now the price has almost doubled to over $30 and no Subscribe and Save.

I did find the three packs for ~20 at the URL below.  Earn their business and maybe Amazon will learn.

column8: I bought these wine gums 9 times since Oct. 2012. the first 8 times I was charged $20.31 the last time I bought them they were $25.21, almost a five dollar increase , but I really like these candies, they are delicious. I went to order another box and I saw $27 and change on the site, I thought ''wow these things are going up like crazy''. Then I clicked on the item and saw the price was almost double of what I was paying $39.95.  I've noticed that a lot of products on Amazon have raised their prices. One item  I was reviewing was $12.49 while I was reading about it, by the time I added it to my cart it was $12.99. This is really annoying. Now I am hooked on these wine gums but I am reluctant to pay twice the price for them. I will see how long I can hold off without them.

column8:
All I can say is wow, each of the three 2 pound bags lasted about a day and a half, I couldn't stop eating them. I used to get small bags of Wine Gums as a child. Now as an adult, I can get three huge bags of them, and I don't even have to leave the house!
The flavor is really good, they are a little soft right out of the bag, but if you leave it open for a few days they harden up quite nicely.

column8:
I have always been a fan of Bassett Wine Gums but they were not available on Amazon, so I decided to give these a try.  Although not as good as Bassett's, these wine gums are very good.  I was impressed with how quickly they arrived (less than a week), as well as the quantity (three large bags).

I tried a few at first but they disappointed me a little.  Didn't seem chewy enough.  However, after I put them in the refrigerator for a few hours, I tried them again.  Wow!  They were a knock-out and I found that I couldn't stop eating the things.  It got to a point where I was eating about 50 in a single sitting -- night after night.  Not exactly a healthy habit.  My son-in-law loves them, too, so I plan on sharing any future purchases with him in order to preserve my waistline.

I recommend this product if you are in the mood for a treat -- maybe you can control your wine gum consumption better than I can.

column8: I truly believe that Gummi is the 5th food group and I typically order candy in 5 lb bags for myself and eat about 1lb a week.  I am a total candy junkie. Swedish Fish, German Raspberries, Fruit Slices, and the rest.  But these wine gums are the BOMB!  Seriously if you have never had them you just need to order some and experience the sublime taste and texture of these.  There are about 5 other brands of wine gums out there but these are the ones you are looking for.  Everyone I've introduced to these gems have had a similar reaction: "What are these? They are amazing".  But I have to caution you: they are very addicting.

column8:
These were truly excellent and you really get a ton of them for the price.  These were the first winegums I have tried and like them way better then any other gummys.  Now I need to try more of them and just yesterday ordered from amazon the Haribo and Maynards winegums to compare.  I will try and update this review after I have had both.

UPDATE: Haribo Wine Gums just arrived.. what a disappointment.  Just over-sized Haribo gummy bears... same way too soft texture.  Flavors are boring also.
UPDATE: Maynards Wines Gums just arrived... Also disappointing... Some were firm.. some were soft.. flavors were pretty strange.  Looks like Gustaf's is the winner for now... and still the best deal by far.

column8: They are DELICIOUS, much firmer than gummibears...almost like good caramels that don't stick to your teeth. The candies themselves are large--more like two of the winegums I am used to--and not overly sweet. The (3) 2.2 lb assortment from Amazon is a great bargain as well (especially on their S&S plan), much less than I have paid elsewhere, even in Canada where winegums are a bit more of a staple in stores. BUT, so few of my favorite purple candies--one bag had only one! I understand that blackcurrant flavoring is more expensive than orange, lemon, lime, etc. but I'd be willing to pay a bit more if the distribution was fairer. Lots of the citrus flavors, and plenty of red for my taste, but the purple is the real deal. I'm keeping my subscription as the kids like the other flavors, but if Gustaf's ever wants to sell me a bag of the purples, I'm all over it!

column8: I found this candy first in a candy shop in Seaside, Oregon.  They were the closest thing to the gummie candy I found in a drug store in Austria that I had found.  Love them!  But I thought I wasn't going to be able to find them again short of shipping them cross country from Oregon.  Then I found them on Amazon and I am a happy woman!  The flavors are so rich and they are not slimy like gummie bears and they don't stick in your teeth.  I want others to try them so Amazon continues to carry them but I don't want too many people to order them and cause them to be out of stock when I want them!  Really really good.

column8:
First, I had not tried Wine Gums before these, so I cannot compare them to other brands of Wine Gums.  However, I can compare them to similar style gummy candy, such as Swedish Fish.  Comparatively, these Wine Gums are chewier, more flavorful & more tart.  The flavors are very distinct, and delicious.  Yes, these are definitely sweet candies, but the intense fruit flavor and tartness make them much more enjoyable and tasty than Swedish Fish or gummy bears.
I would highly recommend trying these if you are a fan of gummy bears or Swedish Fish.
column9: Like Swedish Fish, but WAY better

column8:
Not as sweet as Haribi, Brach's, Trolli's.  nice and chewy.  Not jelly textured like gummi bears. Mild tartness.  Dark purple ones are flavored like black currant.  Yellow is lemon flavored, orange is orange flavored,.  I would say if you like chewy, lightly flavored, not too sweet, large candy, en this is for you.
Two bags later, I think these are the best gummi-type candy hands-down, okay.  No more Haribo or any other gummi. Gustav wine gums all they way!

column8: I ate Maynard's Wine Gums while in England many moons ago and enjoyed them, so I thought I'd try this Dutch brand.  I guess my tastes have changed or something, because I didn't like these as much as those I sampled years ago.  The flavors seem blander.  I actually prefer Jujyfruits.  I guess I am an uncouth American who prefers punched-up fruity flavors to these European flavors.  The gums come in various shapes like diamonds, circles, and rectangles.  They are labeled with names like cider, port, rum, and cognac.  The consistency is good, chewy, and soft.  They don't stick to your teeth, not even dental work.  They are each about the size of a quarter.  Vegans and vegetarians should note that, although the description says they don't contain gelatin, the ingredients list says they do.  I wouldn't order these again, because the flavors are so different from what I currently seek.  If you enjoy these, you get a huge amount delivered.  Frankly, I am going to donate the two unopened bags to a food bank, because I don't see myself eating them.

column8: Let's just say that these have spoiled me and made me not want any other gummies. They just do not compare! The flavors and texture are so much better than typical gummy candies, and the size of each piece is perfect. They are not sticky, even when in warm temperatures. My favorites are the purple and the white/clear ones, but all of them are really good. Anyone with whom I've shared these wine gums immediately love them, too. I have to limit myself to a few at a time, because they are so delicious and so addictive! If you are a fan of gummy candy, you should try these. You will not regret spending the money for this treat.

column8: Funny, how one of the previous reviews is about an American who learned to eat wine gums while living in Denmark. Well, I was born and raised in Denmark and only moved to the US a little over a year ago. Since then, I have tried various wine gums I have picked up in the super market, and well, it is just not the same. But I now tried Gustaf's wine gums and they are wonderful! Compared to the well known Bassets wine gums, I think Gustafs wine gums have much more flavor. They also seem a little softer and although I prefer the slightly harder Bassets, the advantage is that they won't make your jaws hurt.

column8: ...being a "gummy" expert, Gustaf's Wine Gums are the best!  They have a unique texture because they are made with a totally different base than other gummies- they are starch based rather than the American gelatin based product.  The flavor is also very different and appeals to the adult taste - they really do have the hint of wine flavor not the common fruit sweetness.  Heads and shoulders better than Maynard's - my old standby!  Denmark you have surpassed all other similar European and American products.  I have had them on auto-deliver for several years and they are definitely worth the price!!!

column8:
The Cons:  I received three bags of wine gums in a plain brown cardboard box. None of the packaging had any identifying labels--not the manufacturer, not the ingredients, nothing. Just three clear cellophane bags. One of the bags had broken open, and a good third of the gummies were loose in the box. Undaunted, I sampled some of the spilled candy and Did Not Die.

The Pros:  These have to be the absolute best gummies I have ever tasted, bar none. They definitely resemble the candies in the Amazon picture, so I assume they ARE the Gustaf's brand. The flavors are delicious and unique, unlike many of the more kid-centric candies on the market. They are not for the weak of teeth, however, possessing a very persistent but satisfying chewiness. I love all of the flavors, although I cannot necessarily identify them. (Pear! There's definitely pear!)

The Verdict:  I'd give these five stars were it not for the packaging issues. If you're willing to take your life in your hands by eating questionably identifiable gummies, these are definitely worth the money. I say, go for it!

column8:
These Wine Gums kick butt!  Flavor-wise they are much better than just about any gummi bear (except maybe Haribo Gold Bears), and remind me a little bit of these Katje gummis we used to get in German class in High School.  Let me just say I'm lovin' it.

They are a bit firmer than gummi bears, but do not stick to your teeth like Dots or Jujubes.  Highly recommended confection.

column8:
and to a lesser extent the white ones.  The orange, red, green, and yellow are some of the best wine gum flavors I have eaten.  But the purple ones are supposed to be that strong almost border-line "tastes so bad its good can I have another" black currant flavor.  The Gutaf's ones are simply sweet with no discernable flavor.  So sad because one feels that a company that could do such an outstanding job with the other flavors, could do so much better. One caveat:  the white ones are, also, without discernable flavor, however, no respectable wine gum eater really expects too much of them, anyway.  Yes, it is the purple ones that will break your heart.

And should you, actually, like the purple and white ones, I have three bags of rejects I could fish out of the trash for you.

column8:
The texture and chewiness of these Winegums is just like the real deal.  They're not too soft like many of the imitation Winegums tend to be, so in that aspect, they're close to perfect.  However, the flavor is not the same, that's why I can't give them 5 stars.  These simply don't taste as good as the Maynard's, Bassett's, or some of the other kinds that can be found at European candy stores.

The price on these is so incredibly fair that I had to give them 4 stars.  Also, once you've eaten a few of them and you overcome the initial expectations, the flavor actually begins to improve and they can be enjoyed quite vividly.  I love eating these while studying for my exams.

I recommend them as a good alternative for the thrifty Winegums lover who is stuck in the USA and doesn't want to pay $50 on shipping to get the originals from Europe.

column8:
Wine Gums are my favorite candy. I simply can't get enough, especially of the Bassett's Wine Gums. When I visited family in Denmark this summer, I brought back 9 kilos of the stuff. Unfortunately, Bassett's are impossible to find in California, so I scoured the internet in search of good Wine Gums and found these.

Let me tell you, these are an EXCELLENT alternative to the Bassett's brand. They aren't exactly the same, so not as good, but they are excellent in their own right. I highly recommend these to anyone who is a Wine Gums fan. You will not be disappointed.

column8:
Born and raised in America, I had no idea what I was missing until living in Denmark and discovering wine gums.  Since returning to the states 10 years ago I have done my best to find the same brand that I would buy there.  The search continues but my first order of Gustaf's wine gums arrived today and I just may give up the search.  These are excellent wine gums:  tangy, tart, chewy--just about perfect.  Plus, they are noticeably larger than the wine gums I was used to in Europe.  If you like gummy candy it doesn't get any better than this.  Sorry gummy bears, but it's true.
Update:  While the product itself is great, I am very unhappy to see how much the price has increased on these in the last few months.  The subscribe and save option was taken away and the price nearly doubled.  I really love the product, but I can live without it at this price.

column8: I ordered the wine gummies because I remembered loving them as a child, and their intense flavor seemed sealed in my tastebud memory... The shipment included three huge bags of the candy (too few of the black/purple and red ones, IMO--seriously disproportioned toward the white and yellow), and the candy is good. The flavor is almost as I remember--somehow I thikn that childhood gave the candy an extra 'oomph' which this experience now, in adulthood did not share... But, these are still very good gummies, excellent consistency--not too sticky, not too soft. I've shared some (it is a LOT of candy) with others, who loved them as well. I recommend this purchase if you love gummies and want a change from the boring bears...
column9: Delicious, plentiful, almost as good as I remember.

column8:

I will be savoring these until my Dutch supplier comes for a visit in a few weeks!

column8: I have always enjoyed wine gums. I am from Canada where they are widely available and I always brought home a few kilos of Maynards to last me through the time to my next visit. On a whim, I searched Amazon and noted these well-rated wine gums and decided to give them a try. They are excellent! Different in flavor and texture than Maynard's but I find them better. The flavors are more distinct and intense. I am so thrilled! I hope Amazon keeps these on the stock list for a long time. As other have mentioned, there is no alcohol in these candies. There is no fat either, and comparatively low sugar levels. Enjoy them, if you have been looking for wine gums, these are it, and a great buy to boot!!!

column8:
I am not sure what happened to this product but something is very wrong. I used to love these wine guns so much I bought  them for relatives. But my first taste of this new product was an assault on my taste  buds. it was a cheap, oversweet, chemically enhanced,  American candy,tasting like it was laced with aspertame and sorbitol..
The flavors are in fact just one...disguised by color. If you do not look at shape and color you will never be able to taste the difference between the pieces!
And the texture has changed dramatically to something like a gooey, sticky mess.
I tried to return the other 3 bags but without success. I couldn't even get thru a handful of these....things.
The people who have taken over the manufacturing of these delicacies have destroyed everything the brand stood for, in the name of profit by way of cheap ingredients. Theyve miscalculated the whole demographic of the target buyer:  who spends quite a bit more money to have a delicacy that doesn't taste like sugar & detergent.
Obviously I won't be able to buy these anymore. Please let us know how much you need for the ransom to get Gustaf back...
